headline: Federated Investors, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Greetings and welcome to the Federated Investors Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings Call and Webcast. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Ray Hanley, President of Federated Investors management company. Thank you. Mr. Hanley, y
componenttext: Greetings and welcome to the Federated Investors Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings Call and Webcast. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Ray Hanley, President of Federated Investors management company. Thank you. Mr. Hanley, you may begin.

headline: Federated Investors, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning and welcome. Leading today's call will be Chris Donahue, Federated's CEO; and Tom Donahue, Chief Financial Officer. And they'll give some brief remarks before we open up for questions. Joining us for the Q&A will be Debbie Cunningham, CIO of
componenttext:
Good morning and welcome. Leading today's call will be Chris Donahue, Federated's CEO; and Tom Donahue, Chief Financial Officer. And they'll give some brief remarks before we open up for questions. Joining us for the Q&A will be Debbie Cunningham, CIO of Federated Money Markets. 
In the way of forward-looking statements let me say that during today's call, we may make forward-looking statements and we want to note that Federated's actual results could be materially different than the result applied by such statements.  We invited you to review our risk disclosures in our SEC filings. No assurance can be given as to the future results, and Federated assumes no duty to update any of these forward-looking statements.
And with that, I'll turn it over to Chris.

headline: Federated Investors, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ray, and good morning. I will start with a brief review of Federated's recent business performance before turning the call over to Tom to discuss our financials.Looking first at cash management, Money Market assets were up $15 billion from th
componenttext:
Thank you, Ray, and good morning. I will start with a brief review of Federated's recent business performance before turning the call over to Tom to discuss our financials.
Looking first at cash management, Money Market assets were up $15 billion from the prior quarter, with about $3 billion of this coming from the completion of the SunTrust Money Market acquisition. As you can see by looking at the average assets, inflows came in later in the quarter as we've seen at other year ends. So far in January, Money Market assets are down slightly. While market conditions continue to be challenging, our cash management business remains well-positioned, strong and stable.
The fourth quarter saw an uptick in Money Fund Yield waivers to just the beyond the high side of our population us quarter. Tom will comment on the waiver impact in his remarks. We continue to expect that these waivers will not change much until a clear path to higher short-term rates and Fed increases emerges. Debbie will talk about our rate outlook a bit later. 
Our Money Market fund share at the end of the year was about 8.8%. This compares to about 8.5% at year-end '09 and year-end '08, and about 7% in '07 and about 5% at the beginning of the year 2000. On the regulatory front, Federated and many others have responded to the SEC's request for comments to options discussed in the President's working group report. In our view, the changes made in 2010 to Rule 2a-7 which are still being implemented by the industry of further strengthen the framework that has worked exceptionally well for over 30 years. We believe it would be appropriate to allow these measures to be fully implemented and evaluated over a longer time frame before considering this option of additional regulatory changes. 
We continue to support the liquidity bank measure what was proposed by the industry through the ICI Working Group. We see this as an option that will enhance money fund resiliency by offering a source of additional liquidity or high-quality investments, but importantly, does not socialize credit risk and does not provide for a guarantee on the money funds which we believe is neither practical nor necessary.
Turning to other products, we have a variety of equity funds with solid records that we expect to gather assets as the market conditions continue to improve. Gross and net sales in the fourth quarter were strongest in our strategic value dividend fund, which is well-positioned as investors increasingly look for income from equity investments. The Kaufmann Large Cap Fund recently marked its three year anniversary and with its strong performance, achieved strong ratings and positive flows. The Kaufmann Small-cap fund also had positive flows during the fourth quarter. 
Our International group has produced a very solid performance over the last year. We saw positive flows into the international leaders and international strategic value funds in the fourth quarter. On the value side, the Clover Small Value Fund has performed well and has produced positive flows in the fourth quarter. 
While our growth equity fund sales increased about 7% in the fourth quarter from the prior quarter, flows were negative due mainly to outflows in the Prudent Bear fund. We position this fund as an overall enhancement to a portfolio over market cycles, and we believe that this is how most of the shareholders use the fund. Yet, we have seen that the fund tends to acquire assets in down markets that experienced outflows in up markets.  This fund had inflows of $216 million in the third quarter and then moved to outflows of $295 million in the fourth quarter for a swing of over $500 million. 
By looking at the first quarter results for the first few weeks, equity flows had been modestly negative. Within equity separate accounts, outflows were largely due to net redemptions in Quant products, the MBT, SMA and institutional accounts. We won the small-cap growth additional mandate that we expect to find the next quarter with about $120 million.
Looking at bond funds, our growth sales were up slightly in Q4, while net sales decreased from Q3 consistent with industry trends. However, our total return bond fund showed higher growth and net sales compared to Q3, and our high yield funds remained in positive flows. 
Ultrashort products swung from positive in the third quarter to slightly negative in the fourth quarter. On the mutiny bond side, growth sales were higher in Q4 than Q3, but we saw negative flows in the group compared to the positive flows in Q3.
Bond flows are negative in the first couple of weeks of January due in part to a $200 million redemption from total return bond fund from a client reaching its fund asset concentration limit. We've also seen a pickup in mini bond fund redemption. In fixed income separate accounts, we had a solid quarter of net inflows over $800 million, and we expect about $350 million of new assets to fund in the first quarter.
Turning to fund investment performance and looking at year-end Lipper rankings for Federated Equity funds, 25% weighted assets were in the first or second quartile over the last year; 21%, three years; 65%, five years and 83%, 10 years. For bond fund assets of the comparable first and second quartile percentages are 31%, one year; 65%, three years; 74%, five years; and 66%, 10 years.
As of January 26, our managed assets were approximately $356 billion, including $274 billion in money markets, $31 billion in equities and $51 billion in fixed income including our liquidation portfolio. Money market mutual fund assets stand at about $241 billion. So far in January, our money fund assets have ranged between $236 billion and $245 billion and have averaged right about $241 billion. 
Regarding acquisitions, we continue to look for an alliance to further advance our business outside the U.S. as a component of our strategy to expand globally. We remain active in looking for consolidation deals, including money market business. As always, we cannot predict the probability or timing of any potential deals. 
Tom?

headline: Federated Investors, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris. As mentioned in the press release, our results this quarter were impacted by a non-cash impairment charge. Operating income was up from Q3 by $4 million, excluding the $3.2 million impairment charge, it would have been up by $7.2 million
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris. As mentioned in the press release, our results this quarter were impacted by a non-cash impairment charge. Operating income was up from Q3 by $4 million, excluding the $3.2 million impairment charge, it would have been up by $7.2 million. EPS of $0.45 would've been $0.47 excluding the impairment charge up from $0.42 for Q3. 
Money fund yield waivers reduced revenues by about $6 million more in Q4 that in Q3, with about $5 million of this offset by lower related distribution expense. These waivers reduced operating income by $12.3 million for the quarter compared to $11.2 million in the prior quarter. Based on current market conditions and asset levels, we expect these waivers to reduce operating income by about the same amount in the first quarter. We do not expect the impact from waivers to change materially from this level until the market begins to factor in the potential for Fed increases and then again, when the Fed actually begins to increase interest rates. As Chris said, Debbie will comment and give our rate outlook in a few minutes. 
Looking forward, we estimate that gaining another 10 basis points in gross yields will likely reduce the impact of these waivers by about 1/3 from the current level, and a 25 basis point increase would reduce the impact by about 2/3.
Turning to expenses, compensation and related expense was down by $5 million from Q3. Late in the fourth quarter the Board of Directors approved a change to the Executive Compensation Program for 2010 that resulted in a greater percentage of incentive compensation to be paid in the form of restricted stock and previously estimated. The computation expense from the restricted stock program will be recorded over the next three years as the stock is met. This change was made only for 2010 and made up the majority of the reduction in comp compared to Q3.
For Q1, we currently expect compensation and related expense will be in a range of $64 million to $66 million. Of course, there are a number of factors that could move Q1 computation outside this estimate.
Distribution expense was flat despite higher money market fund assets due to higher yield waivers. The impairment charge recorded was due to a decrease in the fair value of certain assets from the acquisition on NDP Advisers, our quantitative equity group. We have approximately $3.5 million in remaining book value in the amortizable assets from this acquisition. 
Looking at our balance sheet, cash and marketable securities totaled $334 million at year-end. This combined with the expected additional cash flows from operations and availability under present debt facilities provides us with significant liquidity to be able to take advantage of acquisition opportunities when they arrive, as well as the ability to fund related contingent payments, share repurchases, dividends, new product fees and other investments, capital expenditures and debt repayments.
Before we open up the call for questions, Debbie, could you please comment on Fed interest rate outlook?

headline: Federated Investors, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, Tom. We are still in the range of 0.25 on the target basis in case anybody missed the announcement this week. The yield curve for money market securities has begun to two to three basis points at this time. It ranges from 20 basis points on average
componenttext:
Sure, Tom. We are still in the range of 0.25 on the target basis in case anybody missed the announcement this week. The yield curve for money market securities has begun to two to three basis points at this time. It ranges from 20 basis points on average on an overnight basis. That's about 80 basis points for one year paper. So again, slightly steeper as that curve and in the 75 to  78 basis points area a quarter ago. 
Our outlook is still that we will not see actual Fed increases until later in the second half of 2011. But we do continue to expect some yield improvement beginning probably in the summer of 2011, based on what will be an expectation of increasing rates and a steeper yield curve that infuses that point. We have begun to reduce the average maturity of our money market funds in anticipation of that steeper yield curve which we feel is more imminent today that it might have been at all during the 2010  time period. We think also that the credit situation in the marketplace is improving, and that also should play through to a bit of a steeper and more positively developed yield curve as the year goes on. And from a regulatory perspective, Chris mentioned the PWT but there a whole host of other regulations and implications from the FDIC, Moody's and others that are developing in a pretty positive sense for the industry and for Federated money market funds franchise in particular. We continue to work diligently on these topics.

headline: Federated Investors, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Debbie. We would like to open the call up for questions now.
componenttext: Thank you, Debbie. We would like to open the call up for questions now.

componenttext: Just to come back, Debbie, to the comments you just made, you really think the Fed you're working assumptions come in the second half of the year. There is a commentary as we said that going cash and up to bring employment down so it seems like they might be a little optimistic, no?

headline: Federated Investors, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: We're looking to the latter part of the second half. So towards the end of the year, but again in anticipation, we think the yield curve will start to season out before then, and that will quite play through positively to the yields on the funds. We're ba
componenttext: We're looking to the latter part of the second half. So towards the end of the year, but again in anticipation, we think the yield curve will start to season out before then, and that will quite play through positively to the yields on the funds. We're basing that on some of the strength we are seeing in the economy today. We continue to see it gather a little bit of steam. Importantly, looking at the affluent the comments what is not seen as much strength as the Fed would like to see is the employment situation. That's obviously the one that the big monitoring item at this point. And we continue to see improvements, there but not to the degree that the Fed would like. 3Q seems to be a focus of the Fed, and that is one that I think is probably a look at more positive in the context of when we might see a rate hike begin to develop in that a good portion of the programs behind us at this point. And although the beginning of it with some resistance from the bond fund perspective with increasing longer-term rates initially, that seems to have developed the little bit more positive of a sense that that is probably a little bit more comfortable with that side of the equation. And as such, with the economy continuing to make improvements on most funds, including the employment fund although not as much as one. We're still working towards the end of the second half of 2011 at this point.

It's not that that hasn't really happened it seems to the globe would the more move to riskier assets and better equity close?

componenttext: Roger, we have seen inflows of late in prior  years, and that's been on an operator occurrence but something regular occurrence. And in other years, we've seen some of that money drift back out as that year progresses. And I think it is much more of a balance sheet and a cash management service orientation than it is money moving to the sidelines and then moving back to the market. That's based on the composition of our customer base.

headline: Federated Investors, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2011

componenttext: One thing I'll comment on, Roger, is the movement of state $4 billion in money market fund assets at Federated from year end until today and is not really all that significant as a trend director and if you look at the average asset him our average assets for the month it has been about 241. When the average assets over all of last year were about 239 and up from the prior quarter of about 237. So these are all rather small types of changes. So yes, you will see these little blips. But I think it's better to look at them in terms or at least it's worthy to look at them in terms of the averages, but it gives you a longer-term picture.

headline: Federated Investors, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: As a follow up to that, what are your thoughts as to why, given the rate environment, money market balances across the industry have remained as high as they have? Obviously there's a lot or money market strategies have expected this to come down a whole
componenttext: As a follow up to that, what are your thoughts as to why, given the rate environment, money market balances across the industry have remained as high as they have? Obviously there's a lot or money market strategies have expected this to come down a whole lot more. There seems to be an awful lot of resiliency.

headline: Federated Investors, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: There's enormous resiliency, and the reason is that especially among our client base, these products are as much a cash management service as they are an investment. And they are an integrated part of an entire cash management system. And therefore, the e
componenttext: There's enormous resiliency, and the reason is that especially among our client base, these products are as much a cash management service as they are an investment. And they are an integrated part of an entire cash management system. And therefore, the efficiency and the type of products they're in our very, very important to this client base. And so, while if you looked at it only as an investment and basis points and things like that, you might come to a different conclusion if you look at exactly the purpose of all the different 50 money funds that Federated has, you would see there serving a lot of cash management service type purposes. And the next thing would be that I think it reflects the confidence that the client base has in money funds in general. And in our case in Federated in particular and handling this amount of money for them.

So that's been a positive or us.

componenttext: One question on the comp side, you're increasing the component on equities and having investor over three years. Obviously that's favorable in terms of the current period cost with that strategy, if you think about what you say rates normalize, Debbie's right that in the back of this year, the broader view is right and maybe not until 2012 or beyond. But if you think about that, increasing the equity component and then that pushes the compensation expense further out, I guess why only do it in 2010? Meaning that if you do it in 2011 then you can start at a lower run rate beginning in the first quarter. And then overtime, obviously your confidence increased investing periods underway. Just wanted to get your view on the 2010 versus why not keeping it on an ongoing program?

headline: Federated Investors, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mike, we came up with that and the board approved it late in 2010 just looking at how the year was going and thought that, that was an appropriate and good thing to do. It sounds like you see that with them too. And we go through our budgeting process and
componenttext: Mike, we came up with that and the board approved it late in 2010 just looking at how the year was going and thought that, that was an appropriate and good thing to do. It sounds like you see that with them too. And we go through our budgeting process and looked at what we expect, and rates are sure a part of the factor. But we think that the things are going to be better in 2011. And so we're going to start the year off and function like that. Things are available to change later in the year as I kind of sand when I gave our range. Our plans are to run it like that.

headline: Federated Investors, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2011

componenttext: On the M&A side. When you guys raised the debt a little while back it seemed like one of the reasons why you're looking for something in the international side. So I guess one, any update there on your thoughts if anything has changed, and second, if you don't see opportunities out there, what else would you want to do with that cash?

headline: Federated Investors, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: First of all, we continue to want to use that cash as we said for acquisitions and especially international. And we continue to look for them and the fact that we don't have one doesn't mean that we still have them in order to try and do that. And as a ph
componenttext: First of all, we continue to want to use that cash as we said for acquisitions and especially international. And we continue to look for them and the fact that we don't have one doesn't mean that we still have them in order to try and do that. And as a philosophy, we tend not to want to have a lot of extra spare cash laying around, although in this environment, we don't feel that having that kind of cash available is really an extraordinary situation. So we are not the least bit uncomfortable in maintaining that. And besides, it's the place where we put the money where the buck stops the interest rate.

headline: Federated Investors, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Michael Kim with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Our next question is from Michael Kim with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Federated Investors, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: First, Chris, I'd be curious to get your take on how the proposed liquidity exchange facility could potentially impact smaller money market fund players that might not necessarily have kind of the resources to deal with either an upfront capital contribut
componenttext: First, Chris, I'd be curious to get your take on how the proposed liquidity exchange facility could potentially impact smaller money market fund players that might not necessarily have kind of the resources to deal with either an upfront capital contribution to the bank or some of the ongoing fees. I know you've talked about having control of your redemption as being the most important factor in terms of being in the money market fund business, but is it reasonable to think that there could be some incremental pressure on the economics of the business, and therefore, some of the smaller players might look to exit?

headline: Federated Investors, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think that could certainly be a factor. Any time you require a payment into, in this case, a liquidity bank, you could have that effect. The charges that are going to come out though are basically charges against the fund assets and therefore the fund y
componenttext: I think that could certainly be a factor. Any time you require a payment into, in this case, a liquidity bank, you could have that effect. The charges that are going to come out though are basically charges against the fund assets and therefore the fund yield. So that part of it, everyone will be playing with the same rates in order to be a participant in the liquidity bank. So that kind of a factored is not much. But overall, I think the comment that while the most important factor is the ability to control redemptions, what I said on that is when a person or an individual or a company can run a money market fund almost indefinitely if they can pull all the redemptions. There are a lot more important factors, and so I'm not trying to quarrel with you about the words, but I want to clear that up as well. So we are strongly in favor of that liquidity bank, and yes, there could be some effect on people who don't want to put any money up at all. And we think it's worth it because of the advantages of such a liquidity bank.

headline: Federated Investors, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: One reminder too, that liquidity facility is designed for participation by all prime funds in the marketplace. It would not be for government funds or municipal funds.
componenttext: One reminder too, that liquidity facility is designed for participation by all prime funds in the marketplace. It would not be for government funds or municipal funds.

componenttext: Just finally, any thoughts on potential changes that are being proposed requiring brokers to be held to fiduciary standard versus a current suitability standard and how that could potentially impact your mutual fund sales across the industry or more specifically, looking at your franchise?

headline: Federated Investors, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: On that subject, we have been one of the thought leaders on this particular subject. One of our attorneys here, Gene Maloney, has done an extensive work on this with the regulators and with various of our clients. And whichever way this ends up going, we
componenttext: On that subject, we have been one of the thought leaders on this particular subject. One of our attorneys here, Gene Maloney, has done an extensive work on this with the regulators and with various of our clients. And whichever way this ends up going, we think we'll be fine with Federated. A lot of clients look at the whole picture and say, okay, what is the relationship I have with my intermediary? And however those rules get characterized, we will be there, ready willing and able to help them solve their challenges or respond to regulatory concerns. Remember, that a lot of our business grew out of our relationship with trust departments that was started in the '70s and has continued through these many decades. And therefore, there's a very strong heritage of understanding and dealing with fiduciary requirements that are obviously broader than suitability requirements. I can't predict how it's going to come out. There's a nice, big, fat proposal that came out this week. But this has gone back and forth, both through Dodd-Frank and through his latest iteration. And it's really tough to predict exactly how it will come out. But we don't think it will hurt us no matter which way it comes out.

headline: Federated Investors, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ken Worthington with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ken Worthington with JPMorgan.

headline: Federated Investors, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: First question for Debbie, on the direction of short-term rate, I know that there's a couple of programs that are changing. You mentioned the FDIC assessment. I think you were quoted in a Bloomberg article along with some others about that possibly pressu
componenttext: First question for Debbie, on the direction of short-term rate, I know that there's a couple of programs that are changing. You mentioned the FDIC assessment. I think you were quoted in a Bloomberg article along with some others about that possibly pressuring short-term rate, I think it's taken out of context so I think Meryl Barclays RBC I think rates go down 10 bps and I think you we're singularly once up five. And in the supplemental financing program, it looks like that had a negative impact. Last time that was wound down. If you think in fact it has wound down again. Do you think it has a negative impact on short-term rates?

headline: Federated Investors, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let's talk about the supplemental financing program first and a little more tangible and predictable would say. That was announced being that wound on sooner. This is with regard obviously to the debt dealing, which will eventually get fixed and then the
componenttext: Let's talk about the supplemental financing program first and a little more tangible and predictable would say. That was announced being that wound on sooner. This is with regard obviously to the debt dealing, which will eventually get fixed and then the supplemental financing will be reintroduced. But in that interim time, as that supplemental financing program is wound down, there will be less collateral in the marketplace and what will end up seeing in our short-term rates on an overnight basis likely going lower and as you know also with regard to treasuries in the marketplace. So we do think that will have a definitive impact. We've seen it happen before. The expectation is that it will happen again. And the question is what is the time frame involved. Will it last for a week? Does it last for a month? How long before the debt dealing gets fixed and it kind of returns to the normal level? With regard to the FDIC we think that's much, much more intangible at this point as there are many variations and questions about how the assessments will be levied. And as such, we really don't feel like at this point there's a quantifiable impact. If I were quoted to saying five basis points, somebody took that out of context. And at this point, we really not offering any kind of guidance, but don't think it's meaningful in any way.

So I think that's probably, in general, the reason why we see feel like again a steeper yield curve for the expectation for that to get steeper as you go forward in 2011 is that the impact on the waivers shouldn't change much.

componenttextpreview: Basically the team with Ultrashort has a longer than money fund type product, it really isn't an automatic flow into the other products. So when we look at them at the top half of our fixed income charge, and every sale we make on the equity side is an in
componenttext: Basically the team with Ultrashort has a longer than money fund type product, it really isn't an automatic flow into the other products. So when we look at them at the top half of our fixed income charge, and every sale we make on the equity side is an individual sale on the equity product. So there's no direct link. Yes we have the relationship. And if you look at the balances where the sales in Ultrashorts over the last three years, they were very, very high and strong in '09 and as I mentioned on the call recently. So but we don't see it as a lock step into the equity I wish I could have you chart like that but it's not the way it works.

headline: Federated Investors, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: We tend to your point, the Ultrashort in this cycle have been a real opportunity for us to expand our business among intermediaries and introduce Federated products to a number of intermediaries that haven't been using that or using us as much as we would
componenttext: We tend to your point, the Ultrashort in this cycle have been a real opportunity for us to expand our business among intermediaries and introduce Federated products to a number of intermediaries that haven't been using that or using us as much as we would like. And so, we're actively trying to leverage that foothold that we've got through the Ultrashort to get a bigger part of the intermediaries business if and when and as they determine when that money should move. In the active marketing efforts through the greater degree than we would've had in the last cycle that you referenced.

componenttext: There was a falloff in some of that. Although if looked at another way, we have still 43% of our equity assets or four and five star in Morningstar is commenting on Lipper and that is up from 36% from the prior quarter. And the percentage of three, four, and five stars is like a 7% up from 82% in the third quarter. And with similar kinds of improvements on the fixed income side. So yes, there are some funds that ran into some challenges. For example, the Kaufmann Fund, the big Kaufmann Fund, which obviously influences the asset totals as well has a large component in about 20% in healthcare stocks. And they're basically supporting strong companies with good fundamentals. And although they participated in an increase in the fourth quarter, I think they were up a little over 9%. The mid-cap area was up more like 14%. And it was part of that 20% in what we consider to be good strong fundamental growth susceptible-type holdings. And we do not participate as much as one might have expected on cyclical stocks. We were in them but didn't have the kind of positions that others had. So we missed a lot of the upside there in that fourth quarter. But Hans and Larry is still positioned in, and that's just one of the stories in the ebb and flow of investment performance.

componenttext: One of the features you're touching on is that because we're going through intermediaries. You don't get the same quick or large response type commentary. And so I'd be inclined to agree with the drift of your question based on my discussions with our people, and that is that, yes, you see some movements. But it is a quick or avalanche-style movements. And it's movements into things like, as you mentioned, are dividend-type stocks of strategic value where people can get a healthy dividend while coming back into the market. So while all those are good, they are not running down the field type positions.

componenttext: Quick question on the M&A environment, just really more about the landscape, think back clearly a couple of years ago when everything was stressed in the buyers market more or less. If it gets on the sell. If you look at it today, things are better, more stable. Is it kind of more back to kind of pre-crisis in terms of supply and demand balance? A lot more buyers and maybe not as many sellers? How do you look at kind of the landscape?

headline: Federated Investors, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: The landscape as it pertains to be that much different. I think that there's going to be more things happening as you settle down and people are feeling better because nobody wants to sell in the crisis. And that's not dealing with people who are closing
componenttext: The landscape as it pertains to be that much different. I think that there's going to be more things happening as you settle down and people are feeling better because nobody wants to sell in the crisis. And that's not dealing with people who are closing down their money fund operation. That's a different subject. So it will be ongoing or the Centers of Excellence, or that crowd, they always are making their own decisions, individually, and I'm pretty sure that they don't want to have a transaction when things are really down. And so I expect things to loosen up a little bit.

headline: Federated Investors, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: A couple of things that might be worthy of mention. Increases in the way we're focusing on the retirement business, which is basically a long-term effort of blocking and tackling and getting on more and more platforms. And we're liking how we're seeing th
componenttext: A couple of things that might be worthy of mention. Increases in the way we're focusing on the retirement business, which is basically a long-term effort of blocking and tackling and getting on more and more platforms. And we're liking how we're seeing that work out, especially because that product, the strategic value dividend product, is pretty good on that front. We're seeing also life on the broker-dealer side for the same reasons. But also inside some of the old distribution, where it's basically back or it hasn't really changed from blocking and tackling. The movement that we talked about earlier of into fiduciary, if that really switches on, then many of our clients are going to need to come to us for discussion and aptitudes and training on how to deal with this new concept. And so if that happens, then that will be another whole press and it will be one where we think Federated will be the indispensable party in order to help explain how that goes. Now frankly, a lot of what's been going on, if you remember by analogy, when Y2K came along and everybody had a complaint about fixing all their computers, and then it turns out that doing the house cleaning was pretty good, this whole regulatory overlay has given us the opportunity to get in with clients and get to studying things. For example, the thread on 12 B-1 one which we don't see really happening right now, but it gives us opportunity to get in with the best clients on ways that don't show up in distribution activity because you have your defense on the field. It moves into positive-type discussions. So it's trying to make a little bit of lemonade out of the lemons that we've been dealing with. And I hesitate to call the distribution program, but we're sure going to make it look like that as well.

Because large cap, it looks like it now has a five star rating but the older and larger one has been underperforming. As you talked about before with all the healthcare. So I was just wondering if maybe you could give us some color in terms of what you're counseling your wholesalers to emphasize just to make more sense to try to retain assets in large one or you're very optimistic for sales on the large cap?

headline: Federated Investors, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's obviously great to retain assets, but we have discovered historically, and I mentioned on these calls many times, that as much as we'd like to, we cannot control redemptions. Yes, you're going to have better performance and that will tend to help wit
componenttext: It's obviously great to retain assets, but we have discovered historically, and I mentioned on these calls many times, that as much as we'd like to, we cannot control redemptions. Yes, you're going to have better performance and that will tend to help with that. But so we just set that one aside. The counseling of our wholesalers is a different issue. Some of the clients that we have, the intermediaries are looking it up to fill sandboxes or to provide the sandboxes that they play in, and the others are looking for the more total concept like total return. It depends on which branch of advisory you're talking about. And our wholesalers dealing with some who are looking at us as applying different sandboxes for them to make the decisions, they are defending the efficacy of each one of those sandboxes and showing how they work and exactly the kinds of stories that I would tell you on the mid-cap Kaufmann Fund. And if they're looking for a large-cap growth fund, then obviously, the Kaufman is a good entry. So that's what it depends on. It's not exactly a deal where we set up on Mount Olympus and try to right the salesmen or the wholesalers on what has to happen. It has to be a collaborative event would be intermediaries to set them up to make the presentation to the actual client.
